aiGymbro.title: Building My First SaaS: AI Gym Bro
aiGymbro.excerpt: The journey of building an AI-powered fitness companion from scratch.

content.intro: Building AI Gym Bro has been one of the most rewarding experiences of my developer journey. What started as a simple ideaâ€”an AI that could help people with their fitness goalsâ€”turned into a full-fledged SaaS product that I'm incredibly proud of.
content.sparkContent: It all began when I noticed how many people struggle to stay consistent with their workouts. They either don't know where to start, get bored with their routines, or simply lack the motivation to keep going. I thought, "What if there was an AI that could be your personal gym buddyâ€”always available, always encouraging, and always adapting to your needs?"
content.techStackIntro: For AI Gym Bro, I chose a modern stack that would allow for rapid development while maintaining high performance:
content.challengesIntro: Building a SaaS isn't just about codingâ€”it's about solving real problems for real people. Some of the biggest challenges I faced included:
content.lessonsIntro: This project taught me invaluable lessons about product development:
content.whatsNextContent: AI Gym Bro is just getting started. I'm working on features like personalized workout plans, progress tracking, and integration with fitness wearables. The goal is to make it the ultimate AI fitness companion that helps everyone achieve their health goals.

sgu.title: My Experience at Swiss German University
sgu.excerpt: A reflection on studying Information Technology at SGU.

content.intro: Choosing Swiss German University (SGU) for my Information Technology degree was one of the best decisions I've ever made. Located in the iconic Prominence Tower in Alam Sutera, SGU offers a unique blend of Indonesian warmth and European academic rigor.
content.campusContent1: Studying at Prominence Tower gives you a different perspective. The modern high-rise setting in the heart of Alam Sutera creates a professional atmosphere that prepares you for the corporate world. From the state-of-the-art computer labs to the stunning city views, every corner of the campus inspires you to aim higher.
content.campusContent2: What makes SGU special is its intimate class sizes. Unlike massive lecture halls at other universities, our classes are small enough that professors know your name. This creates an environment where asking questions and engaging in discussions feels natural.
content.jackTitle: Jack of All Trades? Think Again.
content.jackContent1: When I first started at SGU, I had this nagging worry: "Am I just scratching the surface of everything? Am I becoming a jack of all trades, master of none?" The IT curriculum covers so muchâ€”web development, databases, networking, security, AI, mobile development, and more. It felt overwhelming at times.
content.jackContent2: But as I progressed through my studies, I had a revelation. Learning the breadth of technology isn't a weaknessâ€”it's a superpower. By understanding a little bit of everything, I gained something invaluable: perspective.
content.jackContent3: Now I can see how different pieces of technology connect. I understand why a backend developer needs to think about security, why a frontend developer should understand databases, and why everyone should know the basics of DevOps. This bird's-eye view helped me discover what truly excites me and where I want to go deeper.
content.depthIntro: The broad foundation SGU gave me allowed me to explore and eventually find my passions. For me, it turned out to be:
content.depthConclusion: I wouldn't have discovered these interests if I hadn't been exposed to everything first. The "jack of all trades" approach wasn't spreading me thinâ€”it was helping me find my direction.
content.academicContent: The IT curriculum at SGU is rigorous but rewarding. We don't just learn theoryâ€”we build things. From our first semester, we're writing code, building applications, and working on real-world projects. The professors, many of whom have industry experience, bring practical insights that textbooks simply can't provide.
content.coursesIntro: Some of my favorite courses include:
content.beyondContent1: University life at SGU extends far beyond lectures and assignments. I've had the opportunity to participate in hackathons, tech workshops, and networking events. The IT Symposium, where I showcased the Observer KPU project, was a highlightâ€”our team won Most Favorite Project!
content.beyondContent2: The connections I've made hereâ€”with classmates, professors, and industry professionalsâ€”have opened doors I never knew existed. From internship opportunities to collaborative projects, the SGU network is invaluable.
content.lessonContent1: If you're a student feeling overwhelmed by the breadth of what you're learning, here's my advice: embrace it. Don't worry about being a generalist at first. Use this time to explore, experiment, and discover what truly excites you. The depth will come naturally once you find your passion.
content.lessonContent2: SGU taught me that understanding the landscape of technology is just as important as mastering one specific area. Now, with that foundation, I know exactly where I want to dig deeperâ€”and I have the context to understand how it all fits together.

ctf.title: Competing in PwC Capture The Flag
ctf.excerpt: Diving into cybersecurity challenges at PwC's annual CTF competition.

content.intro: The adrenaline rush of a Capture The Flag (CTF) competition is something every tech enthusiast should experience at least once. When PwC Indonesia announced their annual Hackaday CTF event, I knew I had to participate. Little did I know, it would become one of my most memorable experiences in cybersecurity.
content.whatIsContent: For those unfamiliar, CTF is a cybersecurity competition where participants solve challenges to find hidden "flags"â€”usually strings of text that prove you've successfully exploited a vulnerability or solved a puzzle. It's like a digital treasure hunt, but with hacking.
content.pwcContent1: What made the PwC CTF special was its professional setting. This wasn't just a student competitionâ€”it was organized by one of the Big Four consulting firms, with challenges designed by real cybersecurity professionals. The stakes felt higher, and the learning opportunities were immense.
content.pwcContent2: Walking into the event, I was struck by the diversity of participants. From university students to working professionals, everyone shared a common passion for cybersecurity. The energy was electric.
content.challengesContent1: Some challenges had me scratching my head for hours. I remember one web exploitation challenge where I had to chain multiple vulnerabilities togetherâ€”SQL injection leading to file upload, then using that to achieve remote code execution. It required patience, persistence, and plenty of coffee.
content.challengesContent2: The cryptography challenges were particularly fun. There's something deeply satisfying about cracking an encrypted message and watching the plaintext emerge. Each solved challenge felt like unlocking a secret.
content.takeawaysIntro: Beyond the technical skills, the CTF taught me valuable lessons:
content.pathContent1: Participating in the PwC CTF solidified my interest in cybersecurity. It's not just about hackingâ€”it's about understanding systems at a fundamental level. Every application, every network, every piece of software has potential vulnerabilities, and the work of security professionals is to find and fix them before the bad guys do.
content.pathContent2: Since then, I've continued practicing on platforms like HackTheBox and TryHackMe. The CTF was just the beginning of a journey that I'm excited to continue.
content.adviceIntro: If you're interested in CTF competitions, here's my advice:
content.conclusion: See you at the next CTF! ðŸš©
